Problem:
Analyze the stability of matrices within a linear differential equation system described by \\( \\frac{d \\mathbf{x}}{dt} = M \\mathbf{x} \\), where M is a matrix. Consider the influence of a linear transformation defined by the matrix P, applied as \\( \\mathbf{x}(0) = P\\mathbf{x}_0 \\) where \\( \\mathbf{x}_0 \\) is the initial condition.

If transformation P is applied to initial condition \\( \\mathbf{x}_0 \\) and the system is evolved under \\( \\frac{d \\mathbf{x}}{dt} = M \\mathbf{x} \\) without further modifications, will the solution at time t, \\( \\mathbf{x}(t) \\), be the same as directly evolving \\( \\mathbf{x}_0 \\) under the same system?
Explanation: Applying the matrix P modifies the initial state \\( \\mathbf{x}_0 \\) to P\\( \\mathbf{x}_0 \\), thus changing the trajectory of the system. This difference in initial conditions will generally lead to a different state at any given time t, unless P is a matrix that commutes with the exponential of M times t, \\( e^{Mt} \\).
